name: GDG Dublin - November 2015 meeting
description:
https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-november-2015-meeting-tickets-19545458994

Join us for a great evening. We'll start by some networking and pizzas then we'll have the following talks: 
-Jasmin Ghoul (Google) will be talking about the new EMEA App Hub.
Google’s international headquarters in Dublin is the growth engine for small businesses across (EMEA) Europe, the Middle East and Africa. With mobile devices transforming the way we live, play and work, the AppHub helps app developers from across the region to grow their businesses. 
The diversity of app products and services available can sometimes be daunting for new small and medium developers. The AppHub brings together Google experts from each product category, providing virtual and face to face consultations to help developers to become the next big thing.
Jasmin will present on Google's approach to helping thriving appsters develop, engage and earn with their business.

-Aibhen and Jake (13 and 11 years old app developers!) will present their road safety app, called TelApath and get help for some of it. The app is to warn all rural road users both pedestrian and drivers, about each other. They plan to develop the technology further for use in other areas in the future but are starting by getting this app launched first.

-Doug Sillars (AT&T)
Bad implementations of good ideas: How systemic inattention to performance can kill your mobile app
It seems like common sense: apps that crash are used less than apps that run as expected. Therefore, development resources are often committed to reducing app crashes to improve engagement. However, these same apps often launch without any attention paid to app performance. Recent research shows that customer reaction to slow application performance is similar to crashes: uninstalls, bad reviews, and one-star ratings.
In this talk, Doug will look at several top mobile applications and how poorly implemented features with no consideration for performance led to outages, customer complaints, and low engagement. Through our analysis of applications and by helping development teams raise awareness of performance impacts, these applications have improved their performance – delighting customers with faster applications that do not kill their battery, their data plan, or their patience.
Doug Sillars is a leader in the mobile performance community, focusing on helping developers improve the speed and performance of mobile websites and applications. Doug has presented AT&T’s award winning performance tools at developer conferences around the world. A member of the AT&T Developer Program for the last 11 years, Doug is the technical lead on the performance outreach team. He is the author of O'Reilly's "High Performance Android Apps". In his spare time, Doug enjoys playing soccer with his wife and three children, shooing the muddy dogs off the sofa, and taking care of the various bunnies, chickens and furry goats that they keep on a small farm outside of Seattle.

Please make sure to have your EventBrite ticket.

https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-november-2015-meeting-tickets-19545458994

#android

#admob

#mobile

name: GDG Dublin - January 2016
description:
First meeting for 2016!
Make sure to get your EventBrite ticket.

https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-january-2016-tickets-20753702884

We will have 2 tracks (running at the same time):

1 - Getting to Grips with RxJava on Android (Brendan Fahy)

This is a practical session, bring your laptop

RxJava is a powerful tool for transforming the way we write Java code. The best way to get to grips with it is through practical, hands-on experience. In this session we'll be looking at a sample Android app which uses themoviedb.org API (which some of you may remember from the DevFest hackathon), and applying RxJava to simplify our network calls, our threading, and even our user interaction code. While this will be aimed at Android, most of the content will be valid and applicable for regular Java too.

2 - Talks

Taking control: Input devices at Android ecosystem (Gleb Lebedev)
There are various devices that can be used with Android to get an input from users. The most common way is touch. Let's explore the world beyond screen gestures: remote controls, gamepads, MIDI, USB host interface and network. 
The talk will cover the following topics:
- A shot observation of various wireless and wired input devices
- MIDI API in Android 6.0 
- USB API and USB-to-serial adapters
- ESP8266 microcontroller and UDP messaging

Material Design for web pages (Raphael Savina)
Material Design Lite lets you add a Material Design look and feel to your websites. It doesn’t rely on any JavaScript frameworks and aims to optimize cross-device use, gracefully degrade in older browsers, and offer an experience that is immediately accessible.

name: GDG Dublin - Study Jams: Android for Beginners or Web Optimisation
description:
Join us again this year for a Study Jam.

Ticket: https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-study-jams-android-for-beginners-or-web-optimisation-tickets-21413917604

The format would be the same as we had before for Android, but this time we will have two themes:

-Android for Beginners course:

https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

Approx. 4 weeks - Assumes 6hrs/wk (work at your own pace). Use the grey "Access Course Materials", no need to subscribe and pay. Prerequisites and Requirements: If you are new to programming and don’t know where to start, then this is the course for you!

-Web Optimisation:

This group will follow 3 courses for approximatively the same timeframe as Android:

Responsive Web Design Fundamentals: https://www.udacity.com/courses/ud893

Responsive Images: https://www.udacity.com/courses/ud882

Browser Rendering Optimization: https://www.udacity.com/courses/ud860

Prerequisites and Requirements: You should be comfortable reading and writing HTML and CSS.

We would meet every week for 5 weeks and discuss the past week lessons and share issues, experiences,...

The dates would be Tue, Feb 23, Tue, Mar 01, Tue, Mar 08, Tue, Mar 15, Tue, Mar 29.﻿

Start the lessons and get your tickets here:
https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-study-jams-android-for-beginners-or-web-optimisation-tickets-21413917604﻿

Event Description

name: GDG Dublin - Monthly Event - June 2016
description:
Join us for our regular meeting.

We'll have 3 talks:

Signatures in the digital world by Aurelien Delaguillaumie. Our world is having a digital transformation. A paper-based process is now computerized at the extend that we are trying to eradicate the use of paper. However, paper has a legacy workflow that is deeply embedded in our business workflow. Signature is one of those. In this presentation, we will speak about the past, present and future of Signature. Aurelien Delaguillaumie is working for DocuSign in Technical Support team and he's also a developer hobbyist since 2014 thanks to the GDG community who make him discover this new passion.

Go-ing Places, Go in the travel industry by Paul Mooney, Architect at RyanairLabs. Paul is a Microsoft MVP with a proven track-record delivering exceptionally high-quality software across several industries. Paul is the creator of the Encrypted Token Web Security Design Pattern, and ARMOR, its .NET implementation. He is the #1-rated C# developer in Ireland according to GitHub Awards, a Microsoft Build 2013 Hackathon finalist, a contributing member of OWASP, and the host of insidethecpu.com. Paul focuses on solving complex technical problems while maintaining precise customer-focus.

Enterprise Spreadsheet Apps by James Drew. 
Building Enterprise Applications Using Google Apps, MS Office and Angular. Some of the areas covered include: 

The Case for Spreadsheets

Environments and their restrictions

Debugging

Automated testing using Protractor and Cucumber.js

Unit testing using Jasmine 

Build and deployment 

Using ES6 with Google App Script

UI patterns

Strategy for extending development to LibreOffice Calc

While many of these seem straightforward, the differences between the Google and the Microsoft platform impose massive restrictions on most aspects of development that most developers would consider standard. 

As alway, please make sure to have an EventBrite ticket for the event: https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-monthly-event-june-2016-tickets-26029529022

name: GDG Dublin - Progressive Web App, hands-on (bring your laptop)
description:
A Saturday Hands-on session with Progressive Web Apps

Ticket:

https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-progressive-web-app-hands-on-bring-your-laptop-tickets-26408961916﻿

The aim of this Saturday of practice is to get you started on progressive web apps. It is a bring your laptop event and places will be limited so, please, only register on EventBrite if you are willing to get your hands dirty.

What are Progressive Web Apps?

Progressive Web Apps are experiences that combine the best of the web and the best of apps. They are useful to users from the very first visit in a browser tab, no install required. As the user progressively builds a relationship with the App over time, it becomes more and more powerful.

Experience needed: basic knowledge of javascript.﻿

name: GDG Dublin - DevFest 2016 - #BRINGYOURLAPTOP
description:
We will have few talks but the aim of this event is to make sure you are learning something by practicing or get an answer on an issue you encountered while developing... So this will be a #BRINGYOURLAPTOP event and we expect all attendees to participate!

To get your ticket: https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-devfest-2016-bringyourlaptop-tickets-28498744512

The password BRINGYOURLAPTOP

Saturday: 10.00 to 17.00, talks and codelabs

Sunday: 10.00 to 17.00, hackathon

Talks:

Scaling microservices with Kubernetes: Brave new world by David Gonzalez

David is a polyglot software developer who specialized in distributed (read microservices) and large scale financial systems. He is the author of the book "Developing microservices with Node.js" and he is also working on a book about DevOps and specially Kubernetes (Google Container Engine) which is pretty much a must nowadays as he will show in the talk: "Scaling microservices with Kubernetes: Brave new world" where he will explain the necessity of automating deployments and resource management.

A lap around FireBase by Laurence Moroney

Laurence Moroney has authored more programming books than he can remember.

A well-known speaker at conferences such as Google IO, Microsoft Build, and others, he's passionate about mobile development, and Android in particular. When not messing around with development, he's a published Sci-Fi novelist and produced screenwriter.

Puppy or Muffin? Easily Leverage Machine Learning in Your Apps by Sara Robinson and Bret McGowen

Sara is a Developer Advocate on Google’s Cloud Platform team, where she helps with developer relations through online content, outreach, and events. She has a bachelor’s degree in Business and International Studies from Brandeis University. When she’s not programming, she can be found running, listening to country music, or finding the best ice cream in SF.

Bret is on the Google Cloud Platform team at Google, focusing on developer-oriented products like App Engine, the Cloud Vision API, Firebase and more. He's also an aspiring Node.js developer. Prior to Google, Bret came from Texas, having worked in the cloud industry at Rackspace as a software engineer building the RackConnect hybrid hosting product. Before that, he led engineering teams at e-commerce, non-profit and startup companies. He's often on the running trail, volleyball court or kickball field. Bret earned a bachelor’s degree in computer science from Texas A&M University.﻿

Designing for Product-Market Fit: How to make sure people actually need what you code by Marc C. Lange 

Marc is a Google Design Expert, who cares about entrepreneurship, making products fit people better, and bringing them to market faster. Marc has consulted dozens of startups while involved in nine Google Launchpad Weeks, the Experts Network (now a part of GDE), and other business acceleration programs like Accelerate Korea. He has consulted the German Minister of the Interior, and taught university students in Lyon. Marc has a weak spot for bridging the gap between engineering & design, and is a secret space exploration nerd. He is going to talk about his passion for great products, and how you can know that you are building the right product before you do so.﻿

description:
GDG Dublin-Women Techmakers and Nigma is organising a hub, kindly hosted at Zalando for the Online Qualification Round of Hash Code, a team-based programming competition created by Google for university students and industry professionals. The Online Qualification Round takes place on 23rd February at 18:30 CET and registered teams from Dublin are invited to participate from our hub, which will take place at Zalando, 3 Grand Canal Way.
Top scoring teams from the Online Qualification Round will then be invited to Google’s Paris office to compete in the Final Round of the competition in April.

If you’re interested in joining our hub, find a team (two to four people) and be sure you all register at g.co/hashcode. Make sure to select "GDG Dublin / Women Techmakers / Nigma" from the list of hubs in the Judge System.

name: GDG Dublin, March 2017
description:
Join us for our March event with the following talks:

AR.js - Efficient Augmented Reality for the Web by Jerome Etienne

Augmented Reality is rich in possibilities, it has a lot of applications in fields like history education, science, retail and gaming. The AR.js project is an enabler for these fields. It allows people to easily make AR on the web. It is very fast (it runs 60fps even on 2 year-old phones! )

In the talk, you will see the advantages of web-based AR, what others have created with it in the past and how easy it is to create your own AR experience.

Right now most of you have a phone capable of doing AR without installation. You don't have to wait for everybody to buy AR enabled devices anymore (such as Tango, Moverio...etc.). You already have one, in your pocket! And we will show you how to use it, open-source and free or charge.

Facebook Bots With Your Free Google Cloud Instance by Anthony Isaakidis

Ant will cover look at the bot ecosystem and maybe deep dive a bit on the Messenger API + GCP.

GCP: To infinity and beyond by David Gonzalez

David, our newly appointed Cloud GDE will go over all the Next 17 announcement 

Alerter - An Android Alerting Library by Kevin Murphy (Tapadoo)

A demo of the library, how to use it in your app, and the basics of open sourcing for Android.

Get your tickets:

https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-march-2017-tickets-32827370549

name: GDG Dublin - July 2017
description:
Get your ticket:
https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-july-2017-tickets-36281368550

Join us for an evening of talks!

Confirmed:

Movie Night with TensorFlow by Maurice Gavin
AI first is as hot a topic today as mobile first was in the late 2000’s. Startups, businesses, and developers are releasing fantastic applications each week which is driven by machine learning.
In this session, we’ll give an overview of the technology and explore a quirky use case that should not only inspire you to try it out for yourself but also tackle that age old question of “what should I watch on t.v. tonight? 

Playful apps by Raul Portales People use the apps they enjoy using. Once you are done with a solid app and smooth UX, what's next? The next step is Playful design, a games industry term meaning "delight the user". In this talk you can learn the best practices from a Google Developer Expert on how to get the maximum feedback for the minimum input. Playful design is meaningful animation and transitions as presented in material design, but it is also much more. With the standard animation framework you can add Playful design all the way back to ICS (minSdk=14). Disclaimer: the devil is in the details; make your users happier at the subconscious level and they will be your best marketing assets. 

Givebox by Gianfranco Palumbo How Givebox developed Android and iOS mobile apps to give things away and make others happy. 

#TensorFlow #android #gdg

name: GDG Dublin - Sept 2017 - introducing: Firebase Dublin
description:

We'll introduce a newly created group: Firebase Dublin. As the name suggests, they are planning to be the best group to meet with other Firebase user's/enthusiasts. For their first event, they will be providing 3 talks:

Alan Haverty - Co-founder/technical founder @ Bambooapp.ie
Firebase - Beyond the Database (with bambooapp.ie)
How Bamboo utilises Firebase, with a look/demo into the world of the new Firebase Functions.

Justin Slade
Firebase - Beyond the Database
How Justin Slade utilises Firebase in his business, covering a range of Firebase products, with tips, tricks, and demos.

Esdras Portillo 
Firebase & Redux
Exploring architecting a web app, taking advantage of redux and firebase real-time database

Please make sure to get a ticket for what will be a great Firebase event!

GDG Dublin and Firebase Dublin

name: GDG Dublin - New Year New Project Hackathon 2018
description:
You must have an Eventbrite ticket to get in! Get It Here (https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gdg-dublin-new-year-new-project-hackathon-2018-tickets-41944531222?aff=meetup)

Happy New Year!

It's time to turn over a new leaf, and start something new so we're having a:

New Year New Project Hackathon

Innovation & Ideation Manager at The Stars Group) will be giving a talk first thing on Saturday:

"How NOT to be a ROCKSTAR! - Explaining the art of creative content creation"

name: GDG Dublin - February 2018 - Learn Kotlin!
description:
• What we'll do
** You must have an EventBrite Ticket To Attend - https://goo.gl/HBz7UN **

This month at GDG Dublin we're focussing on Kotlin.

"Hands-on introduction to Kotlin" by Brendan Fahy (Senior Mobile Engineer at Zendesk)

Kotlin Codelabs guided by Brendan Fahy & Maurice Gavin (Lead Android Engineer at Toothpic)

What you'll learn:
How to use the Android Studio's Java to Kotlin converter.
How to write code using Kotlin syntax.
How to use Kotlin lambda expressions and extension functions to reduce boilerplate code and avoid common errors.
How to use built-in standard library functions to extend existing Java class functions.
How Kotlin can help avoid the Billion Dollar Mistake, the NullPointerException.

Don't forget to bring your laptop if you want to participate!

• What to bring
Don't forget to bring your laptop if you want to participate in the CodeLabs.

• Important to know

name: Are you up for a Challenge @ Hashcode 2018

venue.name: Zalando Ireland Ltd.
venue.address_1: 3 Grand Canal Quay. Dublin 2 . D02 WC65

description:
• What we'll do
Hi GDGDublin Members, Think you could come up with a way to optimize Internet coverage for Project Loon balloons? Or how about routing Google Street View cars through Paris?

Step into the shoes of a Google engineer and tackle these types of challenges during Hash Code, a team-based programming competition for students and professionals (18+) across Europe, the Middle East and Africa organized by Google. You pick your team and programming language, we pick a real-life engineering problem to solve. Are you up for the challenge?

REGISTER HERE: g.co/hashcode and once you receive the email from Google, select your hub to be GDG Dublin - WTM

The competition is divided into two stages:

an Online Qualification Round on 1st March at 18:30 CET ( 17.30 GMT )
For this round, your team can participate from wherever you’d like, including one of our Hash Code hubs. Hubs allow for teams in the same location (eg. city or university) to compete side-by-side in a more fun and exciting environment.
a Final Round on 28th April
Top scoring teams from the Online Qualification Round will be invited to Google Dublin to compete in the Final Round of the competition.

Important Note: Once you have registered and received email of confirmation from Google, select your hub in the list: GDG Dublin - WTM Looking Forward to see you all. Cheers, GDG Dublin & Women Techmakers

• What to bring
Laptop and lots of energy :)

• Important to know
Please Register here: g.co/hashcode and once you receive the email from Google, select your hub.

The hub for GDG Dublin is named as follows: GDG Dublin - WTM

name: Women Techmakers 2018 - IWD Celebration
description:
Dear GDG & Women Techmaker members,

We are pleased to announce Women Techmakers 2018 (powered by GDG Dublin) yearly meetup, in order to celebrate IWD 2018. Our topic for this year is "Building a new Horizon" and It will be celebrated on April 14th.

RSVP Here: https://goo.gl/TZ6aDs

For the day, We have planned to share insights and experiences from our speakers.

Speakers:

Sofia Tzima, is a Software Engineer @ Intercom, passionate about Technology, Travels and Psychology. She will be presenting a Security Project that she is building for her Thesis at UCD. More details soon.

Amanda Cavallaro, is a Software Developer, passionate about Cloud technologies, Human Computer Interactions and Chatbots. She works at resolver.co.uk and is a Women Techmakers Lead and Community Organiser at GDG Cloud London and has presented all around the world.
You can chat with her in in an impressive choice of four languages - English, Portuguese, Japanese and Italian.

Amanda will spend the first hour of the workshop explaining conversational apps (Actions on Google) , Dialogflow and how it used and the second hour hosting a workshop, so you'll have a hands-on experience!

We are looking forward to have you over the weekend.

Food & Refreshments will be provided.

Cheers,
GDG Dublin & WTM Dublin

description:
TICKETS HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gdg-dublin-june-2018-tickets-46952290565?aff=meetup

Join us for an evening of talks!

"Tools for Protecting Your Users' Data" - Maurice Gavin (Android Lead, Toothpic)

2018 - the year the average user started to care about data protection. Mainstream media continues to run stories of Cambridge Analytica’s impact on democratic elections, and with the recent introduction of GDPR, data protection continues to be a hot topic.

This talk will focus on security features available from Google Play Services and Google's SafetyNet APIs. We will see how they allow developers to verify the trustworthiness of the devices their apps run on, as well as examples of how to implement them to improve your app’s security.

Next, we will share first hand experience of hardening an Android app that handles medical & health information. We will see where patient data had the potential to be leaked to 3rd parties and the measures taken to resolve this.

In this current climate of heightened user awareness we need to show that we can protect the users of our products, after this session you will be better able to do just that.

“Performance of Mobile Apps” - Doug Sillars (Freelance Developer Advocate/Solutions Architect)

Doug Sillars, author of "High Performance Android Apps" will present a talk that goes over best practices, and shows examples of how improvements made mobile apps run better.

"TensorFlow and AI" - Laurence Moroney (Staff Developer Advocate, Google)

Your next app might be a model! In this talk, Laurence Moroney from the Google Brain team will talk about TensorFlow and how you can use it to train Machine-Learned models that provide inference on input data. It's a whole new paradigm for programming, and it's now available for mobile, IoT and Web developers with TensorFlow Lite and TensorFlow.js!

name: GDG Dublin - July 2018
description:
Get your tickets here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gdg-dublin-july-2018-tickets-47776399497?aff=meetup

Join us for an evening of talks!

(doors open at 6pm, food at 6.30pm, and first talk at 7pm)

"Android Architecture Components- ViewModel, LiveData and Lifecycles" - Henna Singh (Google Developer Challenge Scholar for Android Development Nanodegree)

With architecture guidelines being released at Google I/O 2018 with Android Jetpack and its stable version released. this talk will focus on how MVVM pattern helps

Structuring your app in a way that is robust, testable, and maintainable
Automatically manage activity and fragment lifecycles to avoid memory leaks
Persists Java objects to an SQLite database
The talk will briefly share experiences about google android scholarships in collaboration with Udacity and how that enabled meeting like-minded people across EMEA.

“UI design for an ageing population” - Elenia Carrasco (M.Sc Interactive Digital Media Student - Trinity College)

Smartphones have turned into an important device in people’s everyday life, facilitating many activities like monitoring health or socializing with others. In fact, many senior citizens today use their phones as an assistive technology through their mobile applications. Considering this use of mobile devices by older people, and most importantly that the global population is rapidly ageing, it is now more relevant than ever to design mobile interfaces that focuses on their needs. Such needs relate to certain changes that people face while ageing, which have an impact on how they interact with a mobile device. However, most of the mobile interfaces are not designed optimally for older people. To address this, some usability and accessibility guidelines for older people have been suggested. But, there is no evaluation on how and to what extent the industry is implementing these guidelines, which will be the focus of this talk.

"Why Blockchain Companies Needs UX Design" - Luana Calvancati (UX/UI Designer @ TradeIX)

In a 2017 study on “Trust in Technology”, covering 12,000 people across 11 countries, the HSBC found that 80% of people had never heard of or don’t know what blockchain or distributed ledgers are. In fact, among specific technologies asked about, blockchain was the one least heard about.
What is commonly observed is that the technical jargon deters many from signing up.
Blockchain advancements is financially affecting a great citizens in both underdeveloped and developed nations, and are already doing so through cryptocurrencies and Smart Contracts.
Smart Contracts, which run decentralized applications, democratize industries like the music and energy sectors and the user research carried around the user needs and behavior plays an important part when you need to translate an emerging technology (blockchain), with its own terminology and specificities to the users “language”.

name: GDG Dublin - August 2018 - Diving in to Flutter
description:
Get your ticket here: http://bit.ly/2OTVPEB

Diving In To Flutter:
Get your laptops ready because Matt Sullivan (Flutter Developer Relations Lead, Google) is visiting from Mountain View for a talk and Codelab!

Flutter is Google’s new SDK for building mobile apps on Android and iOS. It’s designed to create fast, fluid apps with customised UI that are compiled natively for each platform. And it’s a whole lot of fun to work in. So let’s dive in to Flutter, explore how it works, and sling some code around to see how far we can get building an app by the end of this talk.

description:

description:

And get your tickets here: http://bit.ly/2CM2Moi

Here's a little breakdown:

Dublin DevFest 2018 will have 11 speakers presenting 13 sessions on 20 technology topics!

name: GDG Dublin - January 2019 - Kotlin
description:
Get your tickets here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gdg-dublin-january-2019-kotlin-tickets-55021083542?aff=meetup

Time to deep dive into Kotlin!
(doors open at 6pm, food at 6.30pm, and first talk at 7pm)

"A seamless journey into the awesome world of Kotlin!" - Tomâs Hanley (Senior Software Engineer,Toast Inc. & Organiser of the Dublin Kotlin Meetup)

"Kotlin DSL & Gradle 5.0" - Justin Slade (Mobile Application Architect, VHI)

"Demystifying Coroutines" - Eamonn Boyle (Software Trainer, Instil Software)

Coroutines are the official solution for tackling asynchronous programming and parallelism in Kotlin. They reached maturity in the latest release but have been widespread for some time, especially within Android projects. Coroutines are an elegant solution which can be applied in isolation or used as a foundation for other frameworks. This talk will provide a simple and definitive picture of how coroutines work, both in terms of the underlying theory and practical examples.

name: GDG Dublin - February 2019 - ML & AI
description:
Hello GDG Dublin members,

We are happy to invite you to our February meetup is All things AI / Machine Learning / Deep Learning.

Save the date: February 26th, 6.30 pm
Location: Google HQ Dublin

Please register here: https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/gdg-dublin-february-2019-machine-learning-ai-tickets-56530922511

Agenda:

6.30 - 7.00 pm Registration / Food/ Welcome
7.00 - 7.20 pm Breaking Barriers: Making Machine Learning a part of your skill set by Johanni Thunstrom, Machine Learning Engineer @ Workday
7.25 - 7.45 pm Intro to Quantum Computing by Caroline McMahon, Software Development Engineer @ Workday
7.50 - 8.05 pm On the journey to AI with Deep Learning by Laura Uzcategui, Software Engineer @ ML Foundations Team in Workday
8.10 - 8.30 pm How to create conversational applications with dialog flow by Justin Slade, Mobile Architect@ VHI

Get to know our Speakers:

Johanni Thunstrom, Machine Learning Engineer @ Workday
She works developing Machine Learning solutions that solve some of the toughest problems at Workday. She specializes in unsupervised learning and network science, impacting integrations and internal server teams at Workday.

Caroline McMahon, Software Development Engineer @ Workday
Member of the Search team at Workday. Caroline’s master thesis was on the topic of Quantum Computing and in this talk Caroline will introduce the topic to attendees. It will focus on how quantum computing differs fundamentally from classical computing; the unique way a quantum computer solves problems and the exciting potential applications. No prior knowledge is assumed but attendees, no matter their background, will gain an understanding of the basics of quantum computing and its potential.

Laura Uzcategui, Software Engineer @ ML Foundations Team in Workday
Currently working on building reliable ML data pipelines on top of Kubernetes and Cloud Technologies. On her spare time she organise Women Techmakers / GDG Dublin and founded Women Who Code Dublin. Laura is a passionate traveller, bookworm and rule breaker.

Justin Slade - Mobile app architect at VHI

name: GDG Dublin - March 2019 - Golang Saturday
description:
This month Allen Thomas Varghese (Senior Software Engineer @Squarespace) and Mihai Todor (Senior Software Engineer @Nitro, Inc.) have volunteered to run a Golang workshop!

Note: This is a Saturday workshop event. Please do not sign up if you will not be able to attend on Saturday the 23rd.
Tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gdg-dublin-march-2019-golang-saturday-tickets-58677435790?aff=meetup

This workshop is an introduction to the Golang programming language and would be most useful if the attendees:

* Has used at least one programming language extensively before
* Are aware of the basic data structures like arrays and key-value stores
* Knows how to read and process contents of a text file
* Understands how the code is split into different modules and linked together
* Knows how a web server works and what is a REST API
* Have some debugging experience

The workshop is split into instructional and experience sessions. Concepts of Go will be discussed and followed by small examples to reinforce the learning. 2 mini-projects will be undertaken to implement multiple concepts working in tandem. The speakers and volunteers will be around to help with questions and making sure everyone is on the same page for lessons. The instructions and solutions to exercises will be available on Github.

Pre-requisites:
-------------
Fully charged laptop with power supplies. Microsoft VSCode and the official Go plugin should be installed prior to attending the workshop

https://code.visualstudio.com/

https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.Go
